messages: 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (11:02): It appears http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issue-76-objection-poll/results?view=compact is behind an ACL that's not open for group members (maybe it is for W3C members, though)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:22): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: OK, I will check into
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:22): it claims that the "results are open to anybody"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:23): but based on what you said, that seems to not be the case
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:24): the compact view is never open to non-members
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:24): (for reasons i don't grok)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:24): the public results are at http://www.w3.org/2002/09/wbs/40318/issue-76-objection-poll/results
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (11:24): Title: Results of Questionnaire ISSUE-76 - Microdata - Straw Poll for Objections - Web-Based Straw-poll and Balloting System (at www.w3.org)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:25): though so far, it's claiming four people replied but that there are no replies
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:26): damn
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:27): the compact view does indeed show the responses
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:27): oh hey, i'm getting weird caching effects
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:27): how odd
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:28): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2, are you saying I should make a backup of the fun Roy Fielding posted there before you take it away?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:29): yeah, archive it while you still got time
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:29): something funky there
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:29): I'm seeing the weirdness too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:29): different content if you reload a few times
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:30): not a mirroring problem... all mirrors are showing the same thing
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:30): must be a DB problem
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:30): thought online polls were generally a solved problem by now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:31): i'm glad roy thinks that quoting monty python consists of a serious and compelling argument
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:31): it'll make the chair's job easier
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:32): ah, that's where that is coming from
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:33): there's worse things to quote

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:34): thought the credibility was lost more in the first sentence which suggests that he hasn't followed how the procedure he is participating in is supposed to work
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:35): at least he didn't quote the Dalai Lama
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:35): or the Obama Peace Prize "war is good" acceptance speech
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:36): not his fault he got the price :)
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:36): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Hmm, they renamed it from the Nobel Peace Prize?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:37): yeah, from now on it will be named after him forever
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:38): and only awarded to people who bomb large numbers of civilians in Afghanistan with predator drones
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:38): At least until someone invades Sweden and renames the prize after themselves, I guess
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:39): you may not have noticed they have also subtly added some implied scare quotes to the name too
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:39): I invaded Sweden but I forgot to bring an army
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:40): gsnedders joined
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:40): I think that prize has always been one long surrealist/absurdist joke
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:40): (btw, I filed a sysreq about the poll issue)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:42): (and talking to systeam on IRC)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:42): speaking of war, let's please start a war against language subtags
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:42): notes that with this type of poll delaying responses to the last moment seems like an obvious benefit
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:43): Since it doesn't give people from the opposite view an oppertunity to debunk any novel points you make
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:44): I don't really like the model we have put in place
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:44): What would you suggest as a better model?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:45): I also note that Sam's suggestion that only people who would otherwise file FOs should respond is rather obviously broken
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:45): I have no idea, I'm just not a fan of the difficulty imposed on keeping the spec as-is
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:46): And the relative ease with which you can create that difficulty
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:46): Since proposing a change is fairly simple

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:47): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: Given the current model of multiple change proposals and non-poll-polls I would suggest that making the responses hidden and encouraging everyone with an opinion to respond would make the process more likely to favour good technical outcomes and less likely to favour people prepared to game the system

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:48): Keeping the spec as-is just requires you have better arguments than the people proposing the change, which should only be difficult if the proposed change is a good one

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:49): personally i think the system is fine, i'm just worried that the decision will be based on arguments that are then not applied consistently to the rest of the spec

Should be "It indicates that no referrer information is to be leaked..." <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-bugzilla/2009Dec/0126.html> ** [Bug 8142] title: "abbr; dfn;" - remove ";" [ms] <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-bugzilla/2009Dec/0125.html> ** [Bug 8156] I think the "the" is extraneous. Should be "It indicates that no referrer information is to be leaked
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:51): e.g. if the reasoning is "each independent bit should be split out" and microdata is considered independent, then we should apply that to everything else too

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:51): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: If the responses are hidden, doesn't that have exactly the same problems as people not posting their responses until the last minute?

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:52): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: It doesn't have the disadvantage of posting early that is, no matter when you post you have to give your arguments based on the prior discussion and not use your response to try to specifically address points made in other responses
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:53): supposes there's some analogy to eBay sniping
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (11:54): where everyone is encouraged to wait until the end in order to get a better deal themselves, but it leads to a worse outcome overall
